content:
Posted: February 17
Early Access Review
								There is so much to be said about Kenshi... I will try my best to structure and condense it in a way easy to go through.First and foremost, Kenshi already is everything it promises to be in the descriptions, no exaggeration. A very important thing to state for an early access indie still in development, in my oppinion.Even in its yet unfinished state, the game world feels real. One might be concerned that a game that tries to be too many things at once might feel disconnected, stitched together and some portions of the gameplay might feel out of place. Kenshi however manages to turn city/base building, classical RPG and open-world exploration in one complex experience, with a reasonable amount of atmosphere on top.Going through this experience is strangely captivating, with a dose of small but noticeable wonder. The first time I realized how weak I was on my own, the first time I realized I can use my other party members to distract guards and shopkeepers so that I can thieve safely while wandering around a shop. The point at which after a lot of building and researching my outpost finally started looking like a small village, my first attempt at raiding an ancient lab that ended with half of my 10-people away team slowly carrying the other half to the nearest village, but with everyone alive and with spoils to show for it...On to the less important things, the game's graphics are good enough considering they are not the focus, but do look a little dated. Soundtrack is good but a bit repetitive.It is stable, in my 40 hours of playing it crashed once, and that was after intense and prolonged Alt+Tabbing to and from it so that is fine in my book.Overall, the game is a great pick for any classical RPG and/or Sandbox fan.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 23
Early Access Review
								Kenshi.Purchased 16th Dec 2014.Playing as  Hive drone, one of 4 playable and original races (minus the obvious humans who have various subraces) whom I named Peaceful Kubo, I started in a Holy Nation farm, mining iron for Cats (the currency of the realm) I scratch a meager living from the rocks, I purchase greenfruits, grown on the farm I now reside on, I endure the soldiers racism as they march past on daily manouvers. I stare off to the north, alone, as the sun rises. I rush into the bar and sell off the last scraps of iron ore, buy food an animal companion and outfit it with baggage. I fill the bags with food and meds. And set off into the unknown abyss that is the desert sands. A scuffle between holy Nation paladins and some bone dogs breaks out, I swoop in, take some furs and a kit of Paladins armour and his blade - he wont be needing them - I now have a bounty of 2500 Cats on my head. As I travel northward to my freedom.Kenshi Includes -Good stuff-Base building, entire villages can be brough up by yoru hand and hard workSquad building and recruitmentInteresting lore and an original world filled with interesting and unique species.A medical system consisting of injuring different parts of the body and having different detrimental effects.An utterly huge open world - But not too big so to as get dull and boreing.Multiuple factions. A dozen or so skills.Research for better, more upgraded items and building to help with your skills and your,Modding community is already bloomingBad/ not good points -Though the game does suffer slow down and the occassional crash (To cut a long list short my PC is far above the recomended specs)The game does take a few seconds to "warm up" and load in textures, models etc - its a big game.The game - if your unprepared for a ruthless world, is utterly brutal, this may be very off puttingThe game is without a doubt poorly optimized - BUT it has improved drastically since I firts purchased it.Yes I have pathetic playtime, owing mainly to my older♥♥♥♥♥♥poor build of a pc when i purchased the game, Now with a more powerful beast and several patches of content and optimisation the game flows - there is some slow down in certain situations (which for a game this size is no bother at all.)

content:
Posted: April 12
Early Access Review
								Like many others, I bought this game a few years ago. Back then I could only think of one thing: rough. Really rough. The UI was simple with very basic sliders, the sand on the ground was smoothed over as if detailed in microsoft paint, and the game was completely unforgiving. I revisited this game in 2017 and I can safely say everything that was rough about the game back then has been improved and ironed out including the unforgiving nature of the game.   This is one of my favorite games i've ever played because it fits a neat niche I didn't know I was searching for.  You create a character or a few and set out into a wasteland. To give players guidance, it is reccomended you start mining and selling until you can safely equip your character(s). From then on is up to the player to do what they wish be it mining, fighting, basebuilding, slaving, stealing, etc. This is a strategy game with real time combat. You select your character and right click on a potential threat, and your character fights. This is melee only combat, so battles are fought with swords, greatswords, katanas, etc. Depending on the skill levels of your characters and how geared they are compared to the threat will determine the outcome of total defeat, or victory. Player controlled characters have skills that can be trained to better cooking, fighting, mining, and smithing. To train these stats, the characters must do the action to progress. Training toughness for example is done by getting your♥♥♥♥♥♥♥whooped. Being downed in a fight and getting back up and surviving increases your toughness exponentially. This means you can stay alive and fight longer. This was such a great mechanic for me; in other strategy games, losing a battle would always have me restart to see if i could change the outcome. With this game however, if i lost a fight, I would try to get the character back up and limp back into town to recover. This mechanic is a small example of how the developer utilizes mistakes and losses and benefits the player with not only lessons learned, but stat boosts as well. The developer of Kenshi has made a game in which stories are unfolding for the player each time they play. With the open nature of this game, I've had plenty of intriguing moments. One in particular was mid game. I had a three characters all who wielded heavy weapons squaring up against seven bandits. My main character Jack swings his enourmous sword and staggers 4. I manevuer the other two around to get a better position but they're caught off gaurd and take damage. My tank named Bard breaks his right arm and has to use his back up weapon. As he swings he gets struck down and knocked out. I send my doctor Soo to heal him while my main character jack fights the remaining bandits. One by one the bandits dropped until the leader strikes down Jack. Soo sees this and enraged, pummels the bandit leader. Jack gets up clutching his broken chest. We need to get back into town before more show up, so Jack picks up bard and throws him over his shoulder. Jack and Soo both crippled and beaten limp three in game hours to find a town to rest their wounds. After resting up, they venture into the wasteland once again. I love this game.

								WARNING: game is in beta.I love the game but atm its very basic.* Can't be a merc.* Can't be a holy nation soldier or anything to do with them.* Very buggy at times.Expanded ^* Swampers, hounds and guards started fight one another. (when they are all the on the same side)* If someone is knocked out (be by you or someone else) they still know who kidnapped them.* Glitching throw walls.* Your meant to get 2 rep with THN (The Holy Nation) when you give them a bounty and not take the reward (doesn't work for me anymore.....could be a mod im using.)(Bug list over)* "Choose to be a thief, a bandit, a rebel, a warlord or a mercenary.You can be a trader, a doctor, a peacekeeper, a business man, an explorer, or a mere slave..."* Warlord - Nope good luck with only 30 people.* Mercenary - Nope only thing is bounties.* A business man - Nope shop counters don't work.And sadly:https://www.lofigames.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=10836"-Limb amputation & robotic replacementsWould have been great fun but unfortunately is a "luxury" feature so I have to drop it"I was really looking forward for that.But in the end i still recommend it why?Because the devs work constantly to make it a better game and one day i believe all these things will be fixed.And its a unique game that i can't get enough of.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2013
Early Access Review
								A really great, addictive and refreshing game to play. Your only task is to survive with or without the help from mercenarys you can hire. Kenshi feels like an RTS although a strong RPG presence exists in the storyline shaped by your actions along with complete randomness, this game displays a tastefull lack of overpowered introductions due to you entering the game as a regular person. A unique and consistently suprising experience enjoyable over many hours.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
Early Access Review
								For anyone who likes RPGs and RTS', this is the perfect combo. I absolutly love this game.It gives alot of freedom, and the progress is good, not too fast, not too slow. Everything is learning by doing. No levels. And if you want to, you can equib a newly recruited peasant with the biggest swords and armor. Although it might not be the best choise, it does give you somewhat of an advantage. When you do get to the point of where you have a secure foothold and a few soldiers, you reap the rewards of your labour. You see and guide your small society of people to advance and trade. And once in a while a few roaming bandits will come by, to keep your guards entertained and help with their training. OR you can just go around being the hermit samurai and doing your best to defeat the bandits you meet, although this will mean death, if you dont have an extremly strong soldier first. And such training can be gained by follwing the traders around, as a bodyguard. This game is a game i have been waiting for, for a long time. Its open ended. And its a perfect RPG sandbox. And its not even done yet. I recommend you to get this game, while its cheap! Its worth it already now. However, if you want a game where you can dive directly into high action, this is not the game for you. This game rewards patience and tactical gameplay.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								I have played this game on and off now for about a year. It starts out as a slow boring day with not much to do, I get on my computer and see the blank white icon on my desktop named Kenshi. (: I click it and a couple day's seem to fly by. I think of how impressive this alpha has been especially because of the small development team (one very dedicated guy!) I am always curious as to what is going to be in the next patch and how it will shape the future of this game. It has so much potential and I look forward to seeing this game a year from now. (12/27/13 now) I highly recommend the this game to anyone willing to give something new a try. The game starts out a little slow, you have to grind a little and run away from a lot lol. But once you do it's well worth the gameplay. (I am a city building/raider)

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Alright, I've only logged 111 hours into this bad boy but, I have to say totally worth the time spent if you're a gamer. It offers an unique challenge depending on how you want to play. It has some kinks for sure but, its worth the buy. Lets not forget how funny it(and its glitches)can be sometimes. I gotta tell ya, seeing your guys running through the wilds with two broken arms is hillarious whe its sped up to max. Now as far as gameplay the x5 mode is really just for travel when you're impatient. Not to mention it can be taxing on your system. The farming system is as good as it gets for the time being and its simple. The hunger system has changed how survival works since I started the game. The combat system is nice to and you can get into some epic battle scenes after awhile. There is a fairly fresh take on the various races with a little mystery heaped onto them as well. You have nations, slavers, bandits and wildlife. Its really a good game and its only going to get bigger from here. The devs are aways on top of their stuff as far as I can tell and the community is pretty good too. Needless to say if you want a different type of experience and challenge give Kenshi a shot. It takes awhile to get used to but, its totally worth the time spent. You can be a trader, a farmer, a thief or, just go around and merc everything. Not to mention the world has an air of mystery about it the whole time. Just roam around and you'll find all kinds of stuff from ruins to, dare I say it, robots!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								If you're a fan of building your own towns that span the ENTIRE GAME WORLD, leading an entire army, hardcore gameplay where if you die you die (but game doesn't end! Carry on with your community and let your previous shell rot in the sands of time!), a free roam game, or hell just swords, katanas, straw hats and ninjas, then this game is for you. It's quite unrivaled in its free roam aspects (base building / attacking towns / trading etc) despite being in an early alpha stage. You can send out different squads of people to different parts of the map, start several towns, just click on a character to move your camera to them. It'll cause quite a micromanagement hassle, as everything keeps going (unless you pause it. It features pause / x2 / x3 / x4 speeds, but lacks a notification / alert system for when people are being attacked - at the moment.) I've been enjoying and will continue to enjoy this game, with future updates sweetening the deal.If you're a fan of "real life simulators" (hardcore elements, no artificial levelling, no hero characters, no scaling item & equipment quality, etc.) or titles like Mount and Blade, Sim City, The Sims, or any other simulator where you control the way a community grows, then this game is definitely for you. Oh, and there's bounty hunting. Kenshi also has a tinge of the post apocalypse feel, being set in the seemingly never-ending desert. (No fast travel! Buildings take a while to build! It's a good time killer :D)

								This is one of those rare games on steam that is pretty good, for me atleast, i have had a great time playing this game since i got it years ago.Tho its taking a long long long time to get anywhere its still happening and i understand that making games takes time.There have been changes to the game over the years, i liked the desert zone they had better then the new map but i am sure i will come to like it just as well after the map is properly done.The game delivers on its squad based gameplay, the combat is fun, the base building is pretty good, the crafting is nice.There is plenty to do in game right now making it worth buying the game right now.But if bugs and an unkown release time is a bother to you then i recommend you wait until after they are done making this epic game before you buy it, but if that is not a problem for you then i recommend this game 100%.

								If you love town building, micro management, squad management, crafting, exploring...the list goes on, then this game is for you, this kind of game is a rare gem in my eye's, I have been a gamer for 18+ years, I have played them all, and all generes, I love this game, there is just so much to do, I was happy with the price I paid and even though this game is still in development I am having tons of fun with it, cooking, farming, looting etc etc, there are many..many factions in this game, so play as a ruthless leader and lead your followers to a life of pillaging and mayhem or be a goodie goodie like me and farm and craft and sell to your allies! this game is a sandbox so imagine the modding community it will get, I do hope it does well I would love to see future DLC., it took a little time getting used to the controls, but after about 15 mins or so I played it like a boss, I definitly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
Early Access Review
								Kenshi is one of those games that once you start playing, it is very difficult to put down. I believe the 9.7 hours that I have on record is from one sitting. Unfortunately, the lack of content, performance issues, and bugs make it hard to come back. The one man development team is hard at work though, and continue to fix these issues and add more content. If you enjoy open world RPGs or city-builder RTS games, this may suit you very well. The desert landscape is fairly bland and I can't say I'm a huge fan of the asian theme, but they have mentioned adding new areas to explore. The map is fairly large and once you begin building your own city and army you won't want to stop. $20.00 is a bit steep at the moment, but I highly recommend Kenshi.

content:
Posted: April 1
Early Access Review
								With the state that it is currently in, Kenshi has proven that it is something worth keeping an eye on with alot of potential in the future. There are alot of options for roleplaying, allowing you to become a trader, a fighter, a bounty hunter, or whatever you feel like. There are alot of options for customization and building your own settlement legitimately feels like your carving out a little peace of the landscape for yourself, giving a sense of achievement and identity in the pretty fully realized world. The whole world is full of other characters and factions for you to interact with and understand and each one has its own set of rules, customs, and trades. you could get pretty invested in trying to make sure you stay on good terms with the faction you prefer, while also attacking and stealing from the ones that act like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s (♥♥♥♥ The Holy Nation). While the game is deffinitly rewarding, it is pretty brutal at the beginning, so dont expect to be crafting vast cities in under 50 hours. That and a few minor bugs do occasionally make the game frustrating, and it can run rather slow at certain times, but none of this really detracts from the overall quality displayed here. all in all, id say that the expiriance outways the minor bugs within it, and i can honestly say that this is a great title for anyone who is into exploration and crafting an identity in a rough and hardened world

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								TL;DR pros and cons:+ Awesome game (unique style, interesting design, great gameplay etc.etc.)+ They did it to beta, yay!~ Seemless blend of RTS and a Town-builder on a solid RPG foundation.~ Tru sandbox (no story-quest-line, just sand, your toys and your imagination)~ Game is mod-able so you can add a sexy-armor, i guess... ~ Still being tested, so expect some instability and small bugs   - Some little bugs and glitches are still out thereNTL;WR (Not Too Long; Will Read):Synopsis: First of all, i have to say that the game's description and videos are quite accurate and trustworthy. Pay a close attention to the game's description, by the way. First goes "free-roaming" then "squad-based" and only then "RPG". While it is indeed an RPG, in the same time it's not. Not in the familiar today wiev that is.  You character(s) has a set of stats and set of skills that could be raised in particular ways. You can equip your character(s) with whatever gear is accessible out there, in any combination possible. You can tune out the phisical appearance of your character(s) in any given way. Basically, you can build your character(s) whatever you want in every possible meaning.  But that's where the "RPG" some may grew accustomed to ends.  In Kenshi nobody will give you a story and send you on the epic quest. Not even a minor quest. Not even to gather 5 rat skulls or deliver a love letter or wake up 11 guards. Every second NPC won't unwrap their soul to you in a complicated system of carefully thought-out dialogues with dozens of possible outcomes. You can't get married. You can't even woo anybody, if only figuratively.     What you can do, however, is to use your imagination, and with help of afeatures given in a first paragraph write your own story by action. Gameplay: Assisted by a dozen of starting conditions, set a foundation to your game. Start as guy with a dog, or try and lead the group of settlers to prosperity of their to-be-built town.  You do not have a direct control over your character(s), instead, it's a traditional RTS\MMO Point-n-click, so you select your character(s) and send them where needed, either to be or to fight, which is also done automatically, based on stats, skills and equipment of your character(s) and those of an enemy.  You may build your own outpost\town, with all the work-stations and various interior set by yourself. Build a shed and fill its inner space with whatever you want. If only it fits there and is available for construction. It's your choise whether that building will become a bar or a hospital. In most cases it's also up for you to decide what role which character will pick: assign them to a mining task, for instance, and their mining skill will progress, which affects the work efficiency. Various traders are available across the vast map, who'll either buy what you've produced, looted, or stole, or gladly sell something to you.  Stealth, stealing and lockpicking is available, and authorities do recognise crimes and in some circumstances - criminals.  Even in it's current state (ver 0.95-ish) map has a very large size and would require some dozen  hours to explore briefly, while only being roughly a 1/2 of a planned map.Conclusion \ impression: All in all, i'd call Kenshi a seemless blend of RTS and Town-Builder on a thick and strong RPG foundation, means, whatever you do - stats and equipment are always there and never neglected.That's said, gameplay is fantastically flawless and natural: Start a character, get some coin, keep wandering alone or hire more characters, build a base, research new tech, build industry, set  people to auto-work... oh, look, your guys didn't go anywhere, it's still they and their stats underneath that thick heavy layer of management and strategy. Quick, assign this guy to guard this girl, and tell her to do the same about him. Boom, Kenshi marriage just happened!    __________________________________________________First version of the review left here for the historical purpose:I want to ask you a few things. Do you remember Fallout? Nah, not that fancy F3 and F:NV, no, i'm talking about '97th Fallout. The world, completely destroyed by nuclear warheads, and then, intensively dried by merciless impartial Sun for over a century, become a harsh, empty desert... that was the world we lived in for a while. We did things, necessary for our cause, we met people, hardened by this hazardous environment, we saw rising nations, mindless bandits, we saw the life after... We were free to go wherever we wish and do whatever we want... Now, do you remember Mount-&-Blade? Where we could roam absolutely free, with no particular cause. We had a party of trustfull associates, we could've trade, fight alone, or swear an oath to a ruller, and fight by their standart. We had to think about provision for out group, so they won't starve and leave us...Before this point we had everything we could possibly want, except one thing...In Kenshi, besides all other things mentioned above, one of possibilities we have is actually settling our own village. Gather some coin, get some bricks and start to build your little paradise in a middle of nowhere. Build it in a trade route, open a tavern and watch caravans going by and leaving you some coin for your goodies. Build a large house and put some beds in, so roaming patrols could rest their feet and heal their wounds. Grow your own crops to make food. Grow your own hemp to make... err... fabric... Beware though, as not only peacefull force roaming the desert. Cruel bandits and mindless cannibals could show up in any hour. They will crave for your supplies, your money, or even your bodies and your life. Build walls, gates, and take deffence of what rightfully yours! Then gather some strenght, and send a squad of trained warriors back, to their den! Take their lives to bring peace across the land and earn respect of other factions. Travel, trade, fight and settle: "The world is yours". I can't forget to mention the party itself. Every buddy you hire is, in fact, a full character with same set of stats as your first created guy. So eventually, if you want to, you can go from a single hero to an army of individuals, and even if "your" character dies, it's not a "Game Over". Everyone are equall, and everyone counts as your character. Besides i'd like to say few things about a graphics. Maybe the textures are not perfect, maybe collisions are not always right, maybe animation is a bit dull sometimes... But, brick hit me, characters even has their FOOT FINGERS modelled! They don't even have this in Skyrim! Anyway, just buy it and help Lo-Fi Games finish this ambitious project and grind this diamond to the brilliant!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's hard to describe exactly what makes this game so addictive and fun. Make no mistake, it's absolutely a work-in-progress, but it's got insane amounts of potential. There's certainly a learning curve, but the game rewards you for trying and failing. Mostly every action you take can build your skill set, even getting♥♥♥♥♥♥kicked by a group of cannibals will make you tougher. If they lock you in a cage, you'll build your skills by trying and failing to escape a few times before making an incredibly satisfying breakout. Once you get your bearings and some respectable equipment, you can group together with some companions and build an outpost as you train your fighting skills and become self-sufficient. Or you can do none of these things. It's a game about creating your own stories.It's also constantly being worked on. The updates are frequent and full of content. Be aware that some updates break certain features of the game, but it doesn't happen very frequently. It's worth investing your time into if you're a fan of Early Access hidden gems and you've got the patience to see it through til the full release. This gets my reccomendation with the expectation that the game continues on the same track it's on now and doesn't get abandoned before it's complete, though I have a good feeling about the devs. They're active in the forums and are great at working with the commuinity.

content:

Early Access Review
								recently i've been sinking dozens of hours into this and i decided i had to write a review. this is a openworld RPG with enormous freedom of choice.. have played since oldland (0.4 or something i think) and this game is what i like to see in RPGs..Story:this is a RPG that plays in a postapocalyptic wasteland thousands (?) of years after an extinction event and now people fight with swords and sticks because technology has mostly been lost..Freedom of Choice:tons of factions each with distinctions that set them apart (cannibals, zealots, ninjas etc..) so you can meaningfully change what kind of playstyle you want to use.. you can be a farmer, raider, trader.. kind of reminds me of x3 and other space-sim gamesHigh Customizability:choose between 4 Races and change your appearance with tons of slidersModding / Workshop:I have no experience with modding but with the tools provided by the devs (FCS - forgotten construction set) you can get at the guts of all the settings ingame that govern how the world and you / the NPCs workActive Development:this game has been here for quite some time and has already changed very much from the first versions and while the experimental branch (testing version) sometimes has bugs its very much enjoyable and improving all the time..

content:
Posted: April 10
Early Access Review
You got to have a good PC to run this! Not because of the graphics but how big the map and the amount of npc/buildings/vegetation/animals inside the game!This game is currently playable! When i bought this game long time ago, I used to think it was abandoned. There was not a lot of things to do and there were a lot of bugs. However most of the old bugs are fixed but there will always be new ones so we must keep reporting!Now enough with the old past and gibberish that no one likes to read them.Let get to the Pros and ConsPros:1.A lot of replayabilities because of the different background stories where you start your game from. (You can add more with mods)2.There is Steam Workshop where you can add mods to the game which adds more fun.3.It is quite fun and you make your own stories.4.You get to build a settlement, make a huge clan and raid big bases.5.You can customize how your character looks.6.Huge map with npcs (You can add more npcs with mods)7.You can adjust your own difficulties.8.The combat is quite in-depth with different body parts which your character can get hit.9.You can imprison people and people can imprison you! (If you add mods, you can become a slaver)10.You can control your settlers at home while you go shopping. Meaning if your character goes to a far away place, you still have full control of both your character and settlers. (Similar to the Sims 3)11.Like most rpgs, there is experiences and stats. So there is grinding!This game has not been abandon yet. Which is already a good sign!Cons:1.Not a lot of content (Mods can counter this problem!)2.Slow update (Who can blame them? Developers are humans too)3.Not really that great graphics (Probably due to how big the map is or my PC need some upgrades!)4.The building mode is quite annoying because of the terrain which bothers me a lot. You will encounter unnecessary slanted buildings similar to Fallout 4 settlement building. (I am the type of person who likes to make pretty bases)5.Crashes a lot after a few hours of gaming so be sure to save a lot! (Probably because i put a lot of mods.)6.Bugs (Just report them!)Meh? Don't know whether it is right or wrong.1.There is no linear story.2.It's a very random game.3.I used collections for my mods.4.No guns. (except turret which is stationary)5.No transport. (Be it horses or vehicles)6.No special skills or perks?This is my review and if the game has updated more content or whether the game is completed or the game is abandoned.I will come back and edit this review.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								To begin with, this is a game for the patient, tedious-loving, and hardcore gamers, that seek a fulfilling experience. If you played the pre-CU SWG, and loved it, then you should feel at home in this. It's slow paced, and requires a bit of thought, and I swear you could write a book based off of the experiences of your character. From being enslaved, escaping, and becoming a bad♥♥♥♥♥ninja, to slaughtering entire cities with your army of samurai. You could, instead, buy a house in one of the towns and live a peaceful life as a trader/farmer. Don't want to buy a house? Build one then, but why stop there? Build a whole damn fortified town, guarded by ninja with freak'n harpoon guns. Great early access game, maybe one of the best. The devs also appear to be fairly active, so I can't recommend it more.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'll admit that at first the game sucked real bad. I had no direction, no purpose, nothing. I was bored and felt like I made a bad purchase (around 5 hours into the game). I only had some basic armor and 1 follower who I named Grandpa.(The game has no storyline so spoilers ->?) I got brutally KO'd and tied up to a pole by the Dust King after I stumbled into his tower. That was when the game opened unfolded before me. I spent 2 days picklocking my way out and with no items weighing me down, I ran away but Grandpa had an injured leg. He didn't make it out. A few people joined my band. Some freely joined, others I paid to join. Now I have purpose. I'm building a town...my own faction. My goal now is to avenge Grandpa and capture the Dust King. Unfortunately, I've♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off most of the other factions, but oh well.The game isn't easy at first and the optimization isn't great. It takes a while to understand. It's basically a do whatever you want type of game with no clear goals. All I know is that I can't...stop...playing...If you like resource management games such as RimWorld or Prison Architect, this might be fore you. There's just more depth to it than most others.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let me start out by saying one of the best games I have ever had the pleasure of owning and playing. I currently give it a 9/10, it will easily be 10/10 once they fix the crashing and the path finding and a few very minor bugs it will be one of the best games out there! I have logged 87 hours currently and I have played all of the starting options and let me tell you just because you start out as a group of 5 nobodies dosnt mean jack! This game is a true open world sandbox! I have played as a travling merchant who brought life saving medic packs to the local police, Iv been a smuggler who had to slip pass the same police to smuggle drugs. I played as a bounty hunter who got his butt handed to him many times and Iv been a bandit with horrible luck! Iv also been a slave and a slaver! and there is so much more to this game! You should give this game a chance even though it has a problem with crashing just be sure to save very often! My hope for this game is for it to become stable and to be moddable I get goose bumps just thinking about the greatmods that can come out of this! I will write a final review once its finished till then play this game and immerse your self in Kenshi!

content:

Early Access Review
								I decided to go wih the freedom seekers for the idea of making a nation and conquering Kenshi. Day one My group and i travel about a 2 minute run from a town to begin building our haven (incase we get overran and have to book it). If you attempt this the first tech you should learn is makeshift walls. By the second day a little post at the top of the screen had said. Aldonia (name of my town) has been noticed by starving bandits. I only had one gate because i thought my walls would hold. Nope i was wrong. 20 bandits came like the Fire nation. They breached my gate. The Old solider and I ran to battle to defend our workers so they could get to safety. They saughtered us all and looted everything. This game is challenging yet appealing at the same time. If you like the sims, with apocalyptic feel and sword fighting. This is your game to try.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Avoid, only in the past few years has this game even started to gather any form of pace , let alone any kind of play. Despite the hundreds of hrs put into this and 5 years of waiting this game is still unplayable. Countless times have i unstalled this game because of it bugg ridden and constantly crashes. Verifying cache, rebuilding the nav mesh, broken pathfinding- still,and endless bug reports filed .Yes the game has an approach and style that come as very appealing to the sandbox/ sim / stratergy. But the implementation of these ideas are ham fisted and generally break the game. Resulting in a gameplay although i paid for 5 years ago, i have never been able to play this game to any sort of conclusion , even if it was a narrative or a play style that i wanted. It will list on the store that its a game for all sorts, And in theory it is- but only if ALL of these options work, which for most part they dont.  Want to be a trader- path finding is iffy- so is trading most of the time. Want to be a fighter- the a.i for your squad and group control is basic at best , no formations , its a drag box -gather all affair point and attack. Its rather warband mount and blade sorta thing only with slight dumber a.i /npcs.Which is a reall shame considering once you have a base set up and start crafting your going to win- full stop. The a.i in the game wont counter u in anyway. This is daft considering this game has factions, but for what ever reason other than some npc running after u to kill / or steal theres no real war going to happen. Its u gathering your troops and attacking what ever u see fit- the game wont counter or gather other factions to help. It wont come kick your♥♥♥♥♥if your getting to big. In all honesty buy warband  if your after a large warfare siege building  faction game. This is quirky and it has it moments , but waiting 5 years for this to come half way playable at best was a step to far for me. Early access has a bad name for good reason, companys came along , promised much and then sat on our money while we got broken codes, false promises, delay after delays in "well fix that patches" this imo was one of those companys.Now the fan boi's on steam will tell u the company lay golden eggs and there ideas for the game out way any gripes u have . Which is total b.s, if u sell something , even if its early access theremust be some form of timeline, steam must address this, because the dev of this game is like"o0 i have another idea" so u have to wait while he codes his idea and then breaks the game again. All along while waited for his first 10 ideas to be fixed. This has been my first 5 years with the makers of this game.  You've been warned.This is the 3rd review- 5 years on

								I've been playing for a long while now and only recently transferred my account from desura to steam, reason for my almost non-existent gameplay time...it's all about preference. All I can say is that this game is unique in its own way and a lot of reviews had gone into details which I would rather not repeat. The developer and maker of kenshi had before worked as a security guard before to make a living while designing this game until recently he got enough money from sales to form a small team. We had waited years for long intervals between updates but he had never disappointed us before. It is his persistence to complete this game, come what may attitude, is the selling point to me. I see it having a lot of potential and modable qualities, his preseverance and persistence at work is the deciding factor. Believe me, it will take some time to get a complete game but it will arrive and you will not be disappointed. It's just quality work by a single master-craftsman with a few helping hands to produce this gem, so you can't expect work to go fast to your liking....he wants it to be the best so for me, take all the time you need, just don't take too long....I hope. ^_^

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								Dang...  I helped to greenlight this game. It was actually the first one I ever voted yes for.  And I've followed it since then, waiting for it to become complete enough for me to want to give it a try. And so I tried it today. And I'm a bit saddened by my disappointment. It reminds me of the old Neverwinter Nights mods that were just vast tracts of open space with occasional randomly spawned monsters. Those weren't games. Those were templates for games. I could open up the NWN toolset and hammer out something like that in 45 minutes. People often did do that.So Kenshii looks like it's just a template for a game. And, given that it's in the .9x version series now, It appears to me that the vision for it may not shift very much. Oh well. :(

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
Early Access Review
								As of January 2017, the play experience Kenshi has offered has declined for several years in ways not attributable to the normal churn of development, to evolving code and ideas, or to the good and bad experiments we hope to see during development. So, I think it is fair to consider it one the very, very few early-access titles that can and should be "reviewed". But, it is an early access title and a normal "review" would be pointless and unfair. Instead I'll summarize why I recommend to hold off deciding to buy or not to buy for now.In a nutshell, what began as a great little gem with a focused and tight presentation and play experience, lacking only in polish and game-mechanic features, has become a bloated, unfocused fever-dream of bad user interaction, inscrutable play, poor reliability, and abysmal rendering performance. The only area that has improved is the length of the checklist of features implemented. But even those feel scattered, random, and not truly essential to furthering the core of play. Kenshi used to seem it was destined to be a master of one thing, now it is an amateur of many.Given that long and steady trajectory, so opposite in direction to its early course, I would recommend holding off on a purchase decision until LoFi releases this and it exits Early Access. Put it in your follow list, keep an eye on it, see how the critics and lets-players you respect get on in their games and hope, as I do, LoFi will prove me utterly wrong with their 1.0, because the early promise and execution were wonderful once and so there is still reason to hope.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS IMPRESSIONSIf and when this game reaches completion, I will update this review as necessary.That being said, for an Early Access game, I would still recommend this to anyone looking for a fun free-roaming open-world RPG. There are various starting scenarios, though ultimately you play a character (or characters) stranded in the middle of nowhere; the overall objective - to be or not to be completed at your leisure - is to recruit other survivors and literally build a community from the ground up that you can all survive the many dangers of the harsh wasteland within. One of the main draws is being able to control upwards of 20+ characters (believe this number will eventually be much, much larger) who are capable of doing various jobs: farmers, scientists, labourers, bounty hunters, warriors, bodyguards, thieves, assassins, engineers, merchants, traders and more; the neat thing here is that all you need to do to train a skill up is to use it, which allows any given character to potentially do anything and everything you'd like them to.Graphics aren't much at the moment, but this game will likely never have a huge emphasis on visuals since you will spend most of the time zoomed out far enough out to not care. The sound is coming along nicely, so far, though it definitely needs more work. AI isn't fully implemented yet and is a bit single-minded, but the 'to-do' list in this area is sounding really promising at this point. Still. The game has a certain addictive quality to it.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Awesome game. It is currently in alpha, but I could (and have) play for hours on end. The mechanics are stellar and, while buggy and incomplete, really make the experience a unique one. You can do just about anything you'd want to do in this game, save for maybe taking on a group of bandits solo. The combat is difficult, so taking on enemies should be done strategically so as to not get yourself killed. Luckily, you can hire as many companions as you'd like to help you take on the baddies. Want to build a base for manufacturing goods, weapons and armor? More power to you! Want to build an army to ravage a nearby town? Better start training! The possibilities are near endless. All in all, I cannot wait for this game to hit 1.0 version. If it keeps going at this rate, I've no doubt it will be extremely successful. GET IT NOW!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has a ton of potential.  And I don't just say that based on the projected features, I base that on how it feels.  As I play it, I get the feeling that as development continues the game world will become a complex and interestng place, and the different facets of the gameplay will compliment it.  It is ambitious, with base building, diplomacy, squad-based tactics, and rpg elements.  If all those come together, it will be an extremely unique game.The development is continuing steadily, it is not a project that is abandoned.  When I read about all the planned features I almost worry that the developer has bitten off more than he can chew, but the progress that has already been made proves otherwise.As it is early access, there is not a large amount of things to do within the game world yet.  However, a significant map expansion and diplomacy/faction system are a couple of the updates coming down the pipe, and if they are as advertised this game would be justified in shedding the "alpha" tag once they are released.A couple of the game mechanics are clunky, it can take 5+ minutes to sell all the items in my squad's inventory due to having to run around to different merchants in the towns.  However, the game attempts to be realistic in many respects and this is one that reflects real life, a merchant likely wouldn't be able to take a dozen sets of armor off someone's hands in real life.  Although I complain about the selling system, I can see that it was purposefully done to make the game seem realistic; it is not just something that was poorly implemented or was not though through well enough.As it is alpha, my characters do get stuck in walls occasionally, it is NOT a common occurrance however.  It is easily fixable too, just save the game and reload with a "reset squat position" option.  This is another example of the thought put into it by the developer; he recognizes that its deveopment status could cause bugs, but implemented a system to allow people to enjoy their experience despite it.  And the bugs really are few and far between for me.I really think this game is going to be something special.  Aside from the planned features, it just has the feel of something that will be a great experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
Early Access Review
Kenshi - A RPG mixed with some tactics and base-buildingDid you ever want to play a RPG where your character was not the chosen one until you achieved the skill to be him? Did you ever want to play a game where you can play with a single or multiple characters with pros and cons for each style? And most of all: Did you want a game with an open world where you can build your own outpost which can produce materials, weapons a.s.o.? If you don't mind some bugs and pathfinding problems (only sometimes) then even the alpha is good for you.You begin with a character for whom you first choose the background. There are a few backgrounds you can choose from and each changes the difficulty (i.e. you get a better weapon or none at all, have a squad or are a loner...). So you begin on a big map (which shall get bigger as the development continues) and don't have a real goal. Except to survive. Bandits may find you very fast and the first thing you REALLY want to do is run away. You need experience. The levelling system is like in Oblivion: You get better as you do it. So now you should get to the next city or a patrol. Bandits are Bandits and you don't have the experience to fight them. Like I said: You are NOT a hero. As you venture to the towns you may find better equipment and buy it from money you got for selling looted stuff from dead bandits or ninjas. Maybe you even find better thins on them, but that does not happen very often. To get the best equipment you need to produce them on your own. As soon as you have got money and found a safe place (not too far from a city would be best) you can begin to build a research bench and begin building an outpost. It takes a lot of time. Many hours (real time, not the ingame time) until you researched everything. You also need to buy some blueprints for better weapons and armors. Now that you have even better equipment you can do more in a fight and if you already have more experience, you can take on at least 1 or 2 enemies at once. Since I only played to this point, I cannot go further with the gameplay. Oh, did I mention you can lose limbs? And need to bandage your wounds? There are no health potions and it takes a lot of time to recover. Conclusion:Pro:- Huge map- Learning by doing- Build your own outpost/city- Research- Limbs can be severed- Different weapons with different playstyle- Research better weapons- Not as easy as most of the games nowadaysCons (at the moment):- Still alpha (includes bugs and similar problems)- No animals- Mines can be build anywhere- World seems very empty- Cities are small- Even if more guys around sometimes 1on1Neutral:- No AAA-gaphics, but still not so bad- Animations

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								I am not recommending this game in it's current state, but I am giving it a thumbs up because of its amazing potential. I mean, seriously, if it gets through EA without the devs abandoning it as so many do, gets the updates it needs and is released in a finished, polished state, then this could be an absolutely amazing open world RPG. It has all the elements of the,perfect game; base building, farming, recruiting town/party member then upgrading them, crafting, research, factions, a huge open world, there are many more elements but I didn't intend for this review to be a long one until I put more time into the game .The reasons that I am not recommending this game in its current state are simple.The terrible, seriously flawed control system.The ridiculously bad camera,The awful performance. I have, literally, a top of the range PC, and the FPS still drops to a level where I want to throw my base unit across the room this is ridiculous for a game in late 2016.I appreciate that it is in EA, and the regular updates make me hopeful that the game will get finished. In the meantime, buy it on sale (unless you want to support the devs, which can only be good for the game), or wait until it is rather more polished.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Let me start off by saying I've been following this game from it's early days. I never thought that this game would turn out as awesome as it has. I thought that it would've remained in it's previously quite barren alpha state. I was wrong.Kenshi is now one of my most favourite games of all time! It's become quite an amazing sandbox experience and I would definitely recommend this game to everyone and anyone. Although the world and lore still has a little building to do at this time, the game and it's features are well worth the £12.99 I paid for it (If its on sale, then even better!) The world is bustling with activity and things to do. You can do literally whatever you want (within reason) and all the hours I've spent playing this game have felt definitely worth it. (Bear in mind that i've played Kenshi off of steam for a long time)This game is truly a hidden gem and I can't wait to see what comes next. HOWEVER, currently this game is based around what YOU MAKE OF IT. If you're looking for storyline or cheap staright up violence then this game isn't for you. It's better played with a mindset of creating your own story (although the factions and lore help direct this I feel). Also the developers are bringing frequent and progressive updates to the game, and the mod community is very active and talented. A plus on the side!10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Clearly an early access game, so a lot of content is still missing. However, it's a very FUN game even now, and since I bought it about a year ago, it's a very DIFFERENT game than what I bought, in a good way. The team has grown and is steadily updating with new and improved content, and they're quite dilligent about squashing bugs.The ambitious idea behind this game is pure sandbox gold, and thus far, I see no indication the game will fall very short of its goals. Even in its current state, it's a game I sink 4-6 hours at a time into. I tend to take long breaks, usually coming back after a big content update overhaul patch, but when I do pick it up, "I think I'll play Kenshi for a bit" always turns into "Wow, I played Kenshi for that long?" It's an addictive game with an extremely promising future.If you enjoy sandbox games, survival games or games that let you make a personal mark on the world, you'll love picking up a guy here and there from the taverns in the local towns, banding together for protection, and watching your recruits grow into hardened warriors and master builders as you carve out your own little piece of the world to call your own. I definitely recommend Kenshi for anyone who like a game that gives you freedom and rewards you for surviving in whatever way you see fit. I also recommend it for those who like to start out with nothing and eventually (a long time into the future) have to means to obtain anything they wish.If I were to compare it to other games... It's a little bit Mount and Blade, a little bit Age of Empires, and just a tiny bit Minecraft. (Tiny bit; you get to build, but you don't get to design your buildings. You can, however, place useful constructions like beds to heal in and containers to store materials and items into these buildings however you choose.)Do bear in mind that Kenshi is still in alpha, so it's a little barren and it does have its bugs. Also keep in mind that Kenshi isn't a game that holds your hand too much. You're plopped down in a world populated with various hostile and neutral factions, and your purpose is to survive however you can. Trade between the cities, start your own society where you mine and farm for resources to sell, or prey on starving bandits until you become bandits yourselves capable of waylaying wealthy merchants and their caravan guards.However, what you do and how you do it is left entirely to you, so do bear in mind that at first, you might feel a bit lost and without direction. Also keep in mind that the world is a dangerous place, and you might lose quite a bit before you start to see gains. Don't be afraid to fall; just speed up the time, and there's a good chance you'll wake up. If you do, you'll be tougher than the last time. Every scar in Kenshi brings you a small step closer to being the big dog in the game.Long story short: If you're thinking about buying Kenshi based purely on what the store page has to say about it, you'll probably be glad you bought it. It's an amibitious game that is slowly doing all it set out to do, and gives you the sense of accomplishment you'd expect. It's paced to be played for the long haul, so if you enjoy open-ended sandboxes where you reap your rewards after many long hours of effort and character growth, this is definitely a game you'll want to consider.

content:

Early Access Review
								     I personally highly recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a challenge, and to anyone who is looking for a fresh new way to play video games.  Yes the Graphics might not be the best at the moment.  Yes it might be in alpha but this game already has so much to offer.  You can create your own faction, and live the way you want to within the game.  You can start a brand new settlement and fight for survival.   You can raid, and mug and terrorise all over the play area.  Make enemies and forge alliances.  This game is well worth the investment and more. Support the creator my buying this game, and reporting bugs and giving suggestions on the forums.  A simply revelutionary way to play a video games, fresh and new.

Support the creator my buying this game, and reporting bugs and giving suggestions on the forums.  A simply revelutionary way to play a video games, fresh and new.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								      In this review we will go over a few of the key features along with the pros and cons of this game. I personally am at a stand point between loving the game and distaining it while keeping in mind the game is in alpha stage. I will explain if and why this game is worth the price.     This game has been in development since 2012, the development cycle has been slow, and an update roughly every two months at the time of this review (3/14/2014) the last known update was February 10th 2014. The game has a few of the features spoken of, the vast land scape that is truly every meaning of the word large. It would take you quite some time to get across the map, I clocked it at 24 minutes on standard speed (the game comes with three speed rates) There are a few things you can do at the beginning of each game, mostly attempt to trade with other factions or cities. As most factions are less than vanilla, the rewards are arguable. You could make a living hunting bandits, or you could simply create a single structure and have the bandits come to you (After maybe 3-4 hours of excessive training). Unless of course you would like to know how it feels to be a three legged cat chased by a pack of wolves. The fighting animations are fairly nice a few clashing of swords, however does get a bit repetitive which is fine considering the game is in alpha. Now there are other things you can work to accomplish if you actually want to feel some progression in the game, consider there is no story or dialogue to guide you in the game at this time  (3/14/2014). There is however a simple tutorial in the options menu. The base building of the game is fairly nice; you can make a nifty manufacturing system mine, research and build. Then find something else to do, which of course is all there is at this current state (which is fine) as the amount of time it takes to get to that point is quite hefty. The amount of available research is quite vast, which will take you at least six to nine hours, depending on which game speed you prefer. Once you have your super industrial enterprise and have the best warriors equipped with the best weaponry and training that the game allows the next step is to find something else to do. That can be a daunting task; you could put little outposts all over the map and make your own little empire with a few squad-mates. 	On another note, there are mods available for the game. The construction kit is easy to get. (http://kenshi.wikia.com/wiki/Category:Modding) Although, the amount of mods aren’t a huge attraction, but they do exist! Now then to pros of the game are. -Awesome concept.-Based on Sword fighting with nice animations. -Build a small empire.-Very large map.-Mod-ableNow for the cons.-Slow development.-Many game breaking bugs.(which is forgivable for an alpha of  course)-The game-play will come to a point where there isn’t much to do and wait for updates like many on the official forum.-The super crash (I clocked it at every 50 minutes) Quite a few of the fellow Kenshi players know what I am talking about.    The question you need to ask yourself before purchasing is the game worth the price tag (I picked the game up for 20 dollars). The developers do need the support I will not argue that, I merely want the buyer to understand what they are getting for their hard earned cash.  As of right now (3/14/2014) the reviews for the game are quite positive, especially from the players themselves and for good reason! The amount of potential for this game is beyond words. I am personally excited about the development, and so are many others. As a personal statement, please understand the game is in alpha stage with slow progression as most alpha stage games are just keep that in mind. If you are in doubt, watch some youtube videos on this game.       Referenceshttp://kenshi.wikia.com/wiki/Category:Moddinghttp://www.desura.com/games/kenshi/reviewshttp://www.indiegamemag.com/alone-no-more-kenshi-goes-the-crowdfunding-route/http://www.lofigames.com/index.php (this is their offical website.)


YouTube™ Video: Kenshi Alpha: Part 1- An Introduction to Kenshi! 

			Views: 15,319		

			Kenshi is a single player free-roaming Role Playing Game, with a Real-Time Strategy influence. Its squad-based, meaning you have a whole team of characters who can split up and go to different ends...

content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
Early Access Review
 Overview – Kenshi version 0.93.28 StableKenshi is an interesting game that's very hard to describe. It's a blend of RPG and RTS that functions quite well. You can dwell in the broken world just by yourself, with a squad of faithful friends, or with an entire army (using a simple mod, you can control up to 256 characters). So, what all does this game offer? Plenty of options you can find in most other RPGs. Be a thief, pawning off stolen goods to make profit, or you can travel the cities to make a living off honest trading with a bull to carry your load. Scavenge the ruins for artifacts with a faithful bonedog companion by your side. Establish outposts/villages/cities, serve a holy purpose, hunt down cannibals, become a leader of an army to sweep over the lands, battle giant creatures, or just chill in a tavern and listen to some of the stories others have to tell. Sounds good, doesn't it, but does it actually work?  The Good   True sandbox experience – almost all that the enemy can do, you can do too (and if not, there are mods for that) Official mod support (with Steam Workshop) – modability can carry the game when the game can no longer carry itself Giant map – even though only about ¼ of the map is implemented so far, it is still quite large, and will become only larger and more diverse as time goes on Updates – disputable (read more in The Bad), but the game is basically being made by a single guy (except for sound, music, and art), so with that taken into account, the game is being updated quite frequently Soundtrack – the music is great, and I applaud the composer for pronouncing the atmosphere of the game with fitting music. Look up the sound engineer and music composer of this game, Kole Hicks. You'll find that the music system of Kenshi is a lot more complex than you might think. Gameplay – All I described in the overview, you can truly do.  Replayability – Even when I explored the map, seen what there is to be seen, I still have the urge to play again and again, just to try a different style, a different race, or just to hang out in the amazing scenery once again   The Bad  Bugs – the game, to be honest, is a buggy mess. Some features that are implemented are not working correctly. For example, mercenaries that you should be able to hire to protect your outpost or to bodyguard you on your adventures don’t work (they just eat your money and act as if they had done the job), clipping textures (your characters can get stuck in inescapable places), shops can get bugged and be opened when they shouldn’t, which leads to guards attacking you, and more Pathfinding – While it’s amazing that you can just click anywhere in the map and your characters automatically go there, it’s not quite so useful when your characters get stuck, run around unnecessarily, etc. Your outpost workers will get stuck in buildings, behind staircases, and in other places. Learning curve – it will take you quite some time to get the hang of the game. This means you won’t be able to experience the game in enough time to be able to claim a refund if you don’t like the game anyway. So, buy at your own risk, knowing you won’t be able to get a refund Long development – the earliest Kenshi development video on the developer’s channel is 9 years ago, where in the description he also states that it’s a pre-alpha footage of something he had been working on for a few years by then. It just might be another decade before we see this game enter at least a beta stage. Still, at least we have an actually playable, feature-rich something, unlike another game that comes to mind – Overgrowth. What’s notable, though, is that even through such a long development the game is still being updated on regular basis, so the developer is definitely determined to see this game through. Dubious PR – I can’t attest to this myself, just thought I should mention it anyway. There has been, allegedly, some controversy. I don’t participate in the forums/steam discussion, so make your own picture of this. For further inquiry, read Extrasmooth's review of the game. If what he says is true, I fear that the developer might dig himself too deep into unfixable bugs. We shall see. Optimization – the game runs like garbage. You will have to contend yourself to playing the game at low/very low if you have older hardware like me. Still, the game will run like♥♥♥♥♥♥in some areas. Be wary. I don’t really care about the graphics as long as the gameplay is fine, but I know some people do care.Phew, that's quite long so far. I don't think I'll be able to write the story of my first serious journey in the end due to character limit, but I might do some "greentext" version later on once I get it written down. Just so you know so far, yes it does indeed "work" and you can experience all I have said you can. With that, I do recommend this game even in its kinda broken state, as I most definitely got my money's worth out of it, and will continue to do so in the future.  But, I still urge you to read through other reviews and to take "The Bad" things into account.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								I am not recommending this game in it's current state, but I am giving it a thumbs up because of its amazing potential. I mean, seriously, if it gets through EA without the devs abandoning it as so many do, gets the updates it needs and is released in a finished, polished state, then this could be an absolutely amazing open world RPG. It has all the elements of the,perfect game; base building, farming, recruiting town/party member then upgrading them, crafting, research, factions, a huge open world, there are many more elements but I didn't intend for this review to be a long one until I put more time into the game .The reasons that I am not recommending this game in its current state are simple.The terrible, seriously flawed control system.The ridiculously bad camera,The awful performance. I have, literally, a top of the range PC, and the FPS still drops to a level where I want to throw my base unit across the room this is ridiculous for a game in late 2016.I appreciate that it is in EA, and the regular updates make me hopeful that the game will get finished. In the meantime, buy it on sale (unless you want to support the devs, which can only be good for the game), or wait until it is rather more polished.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Early Access so far and it is quite interesting. Though character development becomes ruled out after you get to the gist of the game, it is still a unique game. Focused on squad or team members, you create your own town/village and try to excel in the wild lands. Bandits will attack occasionally and you'll have to move your goods to market to make profit. Overall, a fun game and will be even better if final version in the future brings the full integrity of the game to light.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Made a guy that was a mongoloid. Spent 2 days picking a lock, then proceded to lure bandits to the town for easy loot. After much looting I thought it would be a nice time to leave my safety net... I built a small shack, and was loving it, then a evil gang of sand ninjas circled around my shack. The leader emerged yelling "Oi! Come out 'ere pansy". So I complied with the bandits. I walked out there and they offered to be best friends for the "small" price of 2,000 cats. Being the poorfag that bark was, had to decline. They enclosed me, and beat me into a small coma. They lingred there until I woke up and finished the job, and left me out in the desert to die. It took 3 days to die.10/10 would die again

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
Early Access Review
								This game has almost everything you hate from an EArly access game, bugs, crash, things not going as they suppose to be, frame lost, etc... you name it.And it also has everything you love from an early access game, no DLC, dedicated dev team, a LOT of content and hours of fun promised, multiple way to play the game.  By the time I wrote this reviewed I already spent 30 hours, yet I only discovered a very small part of the game. Do you know that the game has not been fully mapped  despite being there for more than a years?? People has only been seeing the west side of the map, and only the northern part. My squad heading south into the swamp as I was looking for soils to start irrigation. Went to internet for bandit locations all to found out the whole area was yet to be mapped, and so the whole east side. You might be that one hero who brave enough for unknown frontier.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Kenshi is an amazing game. You don't start out as some chosen one who can instantly take on an army of guys who have the best weapons in the game with their bare hands, you don't start out as someone who can build a city and have hundreds of people traveling through, you don't start as someone who has lots of money and can buy everything, in Kenshi. You start as a nobody. To even think about beating the weakest enemy you will face in a fight you will have to hire another person to join you, and then train on some dummies for a couple of days, and you'll still probably lose and have to limp back to a hospital bed. 10/10 would get captured by cannibals again.P.SWhile this game is absolutely amazing, please keep in mind this game has been in development for years and it will not be finished any time soon. The developer of this game is basically creating this on his own. although i do believe he has hired outside help. Plus, he's called Captain Deathbeard. give him your money already. check his steam page  HERE.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's half finished, buggy and incredibly fun if you're into the RPG/simulator/strategy genre. It reminds me quite a bit of The Guild 2 (also sold here on Steam). It's a bit unstable. I crash about every 2-3 hoursI made character, picked the origin where you start with a broken arm and a stick in the middle of nowhere. I was the gimpies gimp that have ever gimped. Knowing what to expect from reading other reviews I looked at my map and headed for the nearest town. As expected my crippled self attracted the attention of some bandits on the way. Knowing that fighting them would be brief and pointless I just kept running (bravely) away. Made it to a town and hid. The town guards dispatched the bandits. When it was safe I sauntered back out and started looting, making several trips to the local shops. After I had confiscated all the bandit possesions and profited I headed to the nearest tavern and recruited some backup. I could now confiscate things twice as fast! And that's pretty much how things went for a while. Traveling from town to town, luring bandits along into town guard ambushes, recruiting more and more people. Invested in some backpacks. I even started getting a little bolder and would help the townguards with dispatching these outlaws. My people would get hurt and sometimes even knocked out but I always made sure everyone had first aid kits on them, ready to patch a fallen friend up.  Before I knew it I was leading a group of 20 people, 18 females and 2 males (amazons!),  and we could actually kill single groups of bandits alone without the help of town guards.  It was time to build an outpost!Outpost life is hard. Not a day goes by without getting hassled by bandits, ninjas or cannibals. It didn't take long before I decided to pay the Dust Bandit faction off to leave me alone. One payment and they havent bothered me since. That cut the constand hassling down to about half and made it manageble. I can usually handle any town ambushes but I do sometimes get overrun and have to make a run for it to the closest town (Brink). But I finally finished the wall surrounding my outpost and my little group gets stronger every day!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm writing this during the Alpha 0.62 phase of development. Positives:Self-set goalsInteresting worldEpic mass battlesA wide range of gameplay optionsDetailed battle system and character creationNegatives:Self-set goalsMany bugs (for now)A lot of patience requiredvisually bland environment (endless desert)I got this game as soon as it was released on steam and I can say that it is absolutely fun to play. It has plenty of bugs (for now) and there are many unfinished aspects of the game but that is alright. Whatever this game is lacking right now it makes up for in excess with its gameplay. You do not start strong and there is nothing designed to be "easy." In fact, you will get demolished by anybody at the start of the game. The real fun for me came from building up my squad (I started with two characters, i now have 20) creating a town of my own, and then using my expanding reserves of money, skilled fighters, and tradesmen to utterly dominate anyone who crossed my path. Be warned though, because of the nature of this game it takes a LOT of patience. If you are able to strive through that though then it will be both extremely rewarding and enjoyable for you. I expect many great things as time goes on and can't wait to see the new game dynamics which will make this even better in the future.

That was how i ended up making my decession to buy.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Kenshi takes the base building features of an RTS, straps RPG stats to your "units", and sets you in a world where everything is trying to kill you. Watch as your helpless comrades are beaten and robbed by men with loincloths and iron bars. Watch as evil wolf things sniff out your bleeding body and chomp on you as you try and crawl back to your base. Watch as a larger pack arrives and starts attacking the original pack. Wait for an oppening to send some guys in to help your unconious, bleeding squad. Watch as they too are turned into human chew toys. Watch as even larger animal things show up to the fight. Watch as your guys grab the fallen and get out of the fray. Then watch as the same guys with loincloths come back and beat you up again. 11/10

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm changing my review from a negative one to a positive one. There's just too much potential and fun in this game to hate on it. It has camera control issues, lag, and sometimes incredibly frustrating pathing issues, but I found that cranking down the graphics settings helped with some of those problems. With a great mod that increased the population limit and squad size, I've been having a lot of fun establishing bases and sending out parties to explore. If this game ever reaches completion (the full map accessible, some of the mechanics fixed - i.e. kidnapping/stealth kill which doesn't seem to work) this game will be incredible. In my opinion it's a better Fallout than Fallout - if you don't mind some beta flaws.Holy ♥♥♥♥ the pathing issues tho - those seriously need to be fixed.

content:

Early Access Review
								Spawns in with a dog in a weird spot with a bunch of farmers. Get a feel for the game, do some training.Templars later show up and beat up some evil dogs. I look about and realize there isn't really anything interesting to do in the area.So, I head off. I end up in a town of the one really religious group. I decide to steal some food since I'm starving. Decide to try out the selling back mechanic,get caught for selling uncooked meat to the bartender. Proceed to get demolished by the city guards. Drop the game for two days. come back in and try to escape. Escapes five times before being taken to a different cage in another part of the town.The town gets attacked by ninjas. I take that as my opportunity to run. Realize I have no gear at all at this point.Steal from a dead guard.I am now disguised as a guard. I am not known as an escapee anymore. Leave the town with a big grin on my face.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
Early Access Review
								The team working on this game have managed to create a wild, chaotic, dark, scary, fascinating world which has so many possibilities. This is my first review ever and I've played many games over decades but never felt compelled to write one. I am so excited to see how the full game ends up but I'm in no hurry at all, it's already amazing and unlike anything I have ever played before. It has a replayability factor I havn't felt for a long time, probably since diablo 2. It's scope is pretty groundbreaking. The fact that you don't die outright every time you are attacked is very refreshing and makes for some vey interesting/scary scenario's where members of your squad play dead until you are ready to heal the group. There are many layers to reveal in this game and there are more to come. I want to see it realised to it's full potential, whats the rush ? It's an rpg where you can build bases to eventually become towns, buy houses in towns, trade, craft weapons armor plus pretty much everything, stealing, many many many factions and a sexy roadmap. If you like rpg's, this is a champion, give it a go.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2013
Early Access Review
								Early 2013 review: Get it, you wont regret it. Takes around 2-3 hours to really get a feel for the game. After that, it is all gravy. At the moment, there is no audio, but don't let that hold you back. Just thow on some good jams and start forging your name in this great title.Early 2017 review: It's been nearly 4 years to the date since I first review this. Kenshi has came a long way since the early days, mainly the audio. I do miss the desolation of the old map (all desert) compared to the new biome system, though I agree it's "needed." Kenshi has easily stolen a spot on my list of top 5 games since I've been gaming on the Sega Gen. It has a long way to go, but what's currently here is more than enough for me to be satisfied.
